10 December 1942

Formed Task Force Unit 62.4.3 in accordance with Task Force Commander's dispatch 092212. DeHAVEN, SAUFLEY and MERCURY comprising. Lt. Comdr. Tolman, of the DeHAVEN commanding.

Continued unloading of Mercury at Guadalcanal. Retired tO Tulagi Bay for night.

11 December 1942

Part of Task Force Unit 62.4.3 As before, screening the U.S.S. MERCURY at Lunga Point. Retired to Tulagi Bay for the night.

12 December 1942

While alongside U.S.S. MERCURY in Tulagi Harbor as part of Task Force 62.4.3 at about 0400 Love received orders from the U.S.S. DEHAVEN, to proceed in company, to west and northward of Savo to search for a Japanese destroyer reported burning as a result of a night encounter with out P T boats. In clearing the U.S.S. MERCURY, her cargo boom fouled the U.S.S. SAUFLEY starboard yard arm and carried away all radio transmitting antennae except the TBS. While proceeding at thirty (30) knots received radio report from planes that there were a number of Japanese landing boats along the shore about two (2) miles west of Cape Esperance, THE U.S.S. DEHAVEN detailed the U.S.S. SAUFLEY to investigate those boats and continued to the northwestward to search for the destroyer.

The U.S.S. SAUFLEY requested location of own PT boats from Tulagi (via the U.S.S. DHHAVEN due to lack of transmitter), Received word that there were two (2) still out in the area. After accounting for those two (2), sighted other unindentified boats underway offshore about two (2) miles west of Esperance. Requested U.S.S. DEHAVEN to again check location of our own PT boats and stated that the USS SAUFLEY was going to open fire on boats sighted. Received no further information on own boats and opened fire at about 12000 yards to prevent boats from reaching shore. After five salvos received word that another U.S. PT boat had reported being fired upon. Ceased fire. Did not observe any direct hits on PT boats and believe no damage done. Continued cruising offshore in the vicinity. Amplifiying reports received indicating that one previously unaccounted for PT boat was aground and other PT boats were proceeding in to assist, taking off boat or crew as feasible.

During the above period operations were seriously hampered by fact that PT boats and planes were on the same frequency. Testing and tuning of plane transmitters interfered with operational orders and reports between PT boats, the U.S.S. DEHAVEN, U.S.S. SAUFLEY and Tulagi.

The U.S.S. DEHAVEN made no contact, and after receiving plane report that no Japanese ships were in the vicinity returned to the vicinity of Cape Esperance and directed the U.S.S. SAUFLEY report to Commander Task Group 66.7.1 in U.S.S. MINNEAPOLIS, Captain C.E. ROSENDAHL, Commanding, at Tulagi, for further instructions.

Returned, searched area west and south of Savo for survivors of lost PT boat. Found wreckage of PT boat which apparently had caught fire and then blown up. No survivors were found.

13 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 66.7.1. As before in accordance with operation order of 12 December 1942, signed by Captain C. E. ROSENDAHL, Commanding U.S.S. MINNEAPOLIS. Proceeding from Tulagi Bay to Espirito Santos escorting U.S.S. MINNEAPOLIS in company with U.S.S. MEADE and U.S.S. NAVAJO.

About 1925 made sound contact, range 900 yards, bearing 300 (T). Made deliberate attack and at 1932 dropped seven charges pattern firing time from recorder. Continued to search area. 2044 sighted small oil slick, weak echoes and fired three charges. Continued to search area until 2142 at which time rejoined convoy.

14 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 66.7.1. As before. Screening operations enroute to Espirito Santos from Tulagi Bay.

Submarine contact at 1540 bearing 185 (T) at 1100 yards. Own ship course 160, speed 12 knots. Came right for deliberate attack. Increased speed to 15 knots. 1542 fired first charge of a nine charge medium pattern. Searched area for one hour 23 minutes and unable to pick up further contact.

15 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 66.4.7.1. As before. Screening escorts to Espirito Santos from Tulagi Bay.

16 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 66.4.7.1. As before. Screening operations enroute Espirito Santos from Tulagi Bay.

Arrived Espirito Santos late afternoon. Detached from Task Unit 66.7.1.

17 December 1942

Moored alongside U.S.S. ZANE and U.S.S. TREVOR. Underway at 1030 Love. Part of Task Group 67. Cruisers U.S.S. LOUISVILLE and U.S.S. HELENA, Task Unit 67.2.1. U.S.S. HONULULU and U.S.S. COLUMBIA Task Unit 67.2.2. Rear Admiral in the U.S.S. HONULULU Commanding. Escorting destroyers, U.S.S. FLETCHER, U.S.S. DAYTON, U.5.5. LANG, U.S.S. SAUFLEY. Captain Briscoe in the U.S.S. FLETCHER Commanding.

Operating in accordance with Rear Admiral W.L. Ainsworth's operation order 2-42 of 17 December 1942 and operation dispatch 160352 from COMSOPAC.

0800 Moored at Espirito Santos

18 December 1942

Part of Task Group 67 as before. Screening cruisers and patrolling area indicated by positions shown below.

19 December 1942

Part of Task Group 67 as before. Screening cruisers in area indicated by positions listed below.

20 December 1942

Part of Task Group 67 as before - Screening cruisers and patrolling area indicated by positions shown below.

21 December 1942

Part of Task Group 67 as before - Screening cruisers and patrolling area indicated by positions shown below.

22 December 1942

Part of Task Group 67 as before - Screening cruisers and patrolling area indicated by positions shown below.

2000 Moored at Espirito Santos

23 December 1942

Moored at Espirito Santos Bay.

24 December 1942

Part of Task Group 67 - Patrolling area outside Espirito Santos Bay in accordance with Task Affirm of Harbor Defense Plan #2.

25 December 1942

Patrolling as before - Relieved at 1200 Love and returned to mooring at Espirito Santos Bay.

26 December 1942

Moored at Espirito Santos Bay.

27 December 1942

Underway at 0600 Love in company with the USS LANG to rendezvous with Task Unit 62.4.3. Joined Task Unit enroute to Guadalcanal, composed of transports USS REPUBLIC, USS PRESIDENT GRANT, and USS WILLIAM HOLBROOK and escorting destroyers REID, CUMMINGS, CASE. Commander Task Unit in REPUBLIC - Captain T. G. Peyton.

Operating under operational plan #1-42 dated 19 Decenber 1942 signed by Captain Peyton.

28 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 62-43 as before enroute to Guadalcanal, Escorting and screening transports.

1200 Course made good last twenty-four hours 290 distance 218 miles.

29 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 62.4.3 as before enroute to Guadalcanal. Escorting and screening transports.

1200 Course made good last 24 hours 305 (T) Distance 218 miles.

30 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 62.4.3 as before, Arrived off Lunga Point, Guadalcanal Island. Screened unloading operations of transports. Retired eastward through Lunga Channel for patrol duty during night.

31 December 1942

Part of Task Unit 62.4.3 as before. Screening unloading operations of transports. Task Unit retired to Tulagi Harbor for night.
November 1-4 Moored alongside USS DIXIE in Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China. Emergency repairs being accomplished by USS DIXIE. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Rear Admiral JOY in USS NASHVILLE.)

November 5 Moored alongside USS DIXIE in Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Rear Admiral JOY in USS NASHVILLE.)

Conducted dock trial during the morning. Underway at 1140 in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY THREE dispatch 040445. Proceeded down stream to Yangtze entrance buoy. Anchored at 1615 in South Channel of Yangtze River. At 1900 relieved USS CONY as Harbor Entrance Control Vessel.
November 6-10 Anchored in South Channel of Yangtze River, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Lieutenant Commander SILK in USS SAUFLEY.)

November 11 Anchored in South Channel of Yangtze River, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Lieutenant Commander SILK in USS SAUFLEY.)

Relieved as Harbor Entrance Control Vessel by USS WALLER at 0931. Underway for Shanghai at 1001 in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY THREE dispatch 101213. At 1435 moored to USS ORVETTA in the Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China.

November 12 Moored alongside USS ORVETTA in Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Rear Admiral JOY, Commander Task Force SEVENTY THREE, in USS NASHVILLE.)

Underway from alongside USS ORVETTA at 0525 in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY THREE dispatch 101213 of November 1945. Proceeding to Okinawa Gunto. Took station in the Yangtze River as escort for USS HOCKING.

November 13 Steaming enroute from Shanghai, China to Okinawa Gunto, escorting USS HOCKING. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander C.D. SCHUTZ, USNR, in USS HOCKING.)

During the morning test fired 5"/38 VT projectiles. Detached from USS HOCKING at 1905. Proceeding independently to Okinawa Gunto.

November 14 Steaming singly enroute from Shanghai, China to Okinawa Gunto.

Entered Buckner Bay, Okinawa Shima, Nansei Shoto and anchored at 0742.

November 15 Anchored in Buckner Bay, Okinawa Shima, Nansei Shoto.

Underway at 1000 in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY THREE dispatch 101213 of November 1945. Proceeding to Shanghai, China.

November 16 Steaming singly enroute from Okinawa Gunto to Shanghai, China.

Entered Whangpoo River at 0848. Moored to USS ORVETTA at 1015.
November 17-18 Moored to USS ORVETTA in the Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China. Emergency repairs being accomplished by USS SIERRA. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Rear Admiral JOY in USS SAINT PAUL.)

November 19 Moored to USS ORVETTA in the Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Rear Admiral Joy in USS SAINT PAUL.)

Underway from alongside USS ORVETTA at 0840 in accordance with verbal orders from Commander Task Group SEVENTY THREE POINT TWO. Anchored at 1213 in South Channel of Yangtze River. Assumed Harbor Entrance Control Vessel duty from USS WALLER at 1245.
November 20-25 Anchored in South Channel of Yangtze River, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Lieutenant Commander SILK, in USS SAUFLEY.)

November 26 Anchored in South Channel of Yangtze River, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Lieutenant Commander SILK, USN, in USS SAUFLEY.)

Underway at 0911 for Tungsha Banks to transfer pilots. Anchored at 1145 in vicinity of Yangtze Entrance Buoy.

November 27 Anchored in South Channel of Yangtze River, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Lieutenant Commander SILK, USN, in USS SAUFLEY.)

Relieved as Harbor Entrance Control Vessel by USS PHILIP at 1330. Underway at 1334 in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY THREE POINT TWO dispatch 260046, proceeding to Shanghai, China. Moored to USS ROBINSON at 1735 in the Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China.
November 28-30 Moored to USS ROBINSON in the Whangpoo River, Shanghai, China. (Senior Officer Present Afloat Rear Admiral JOY in USS SAINT PAUL.)

May 1. Anchored in Tawi Tawi Bay, Tawi Tawi Island, Sulu Archipelago, Philippine Islands. (SOPA Commander Task Group SEVENTY THREE POINT TWO in USS POCOMOKE). At 1540 underway in accordance with Commander Seventh Amphibious Force secret dis- patch 30013 of 30 April 1945, in company with units of Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN, consisting of 7 YMSs and 1 LCS, (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander NEVILLE in USS SAUFLEY). Departed Tawi Tawi, Sulu Archipelago, for Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands.

Steaming enroute from Tawi Tawi, Sulu Archipelago, to Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands, with units of Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN consisting of 7 YMSs and 1 LCS, (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander NEVILLE in USS SAUFLEY). 0945 Exercised 40 MM gun crews at burst practice. Departed from Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN pursuant to verbal orders Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN. Arrived Zamboanga 1123 and anchored in Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Philippine Islands, at 1150.

May 3. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Philippine Islands. (SOPA in USS STONEWALL). 1644 In accordance with Commander Seventh Amphibious Force dispatch 30031, Commander NEVILLE, Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN, transferred flag to LCS 766. 1802 Underway in accordance with Commander Seventh Amphibious Force dispatch 30031. Departed from Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands, for Leyte Island, Philippine Islands.

May 4. Steaming enroute from Zamboanga, Mindanao Island, Philippine Islands, to Leyte Gulf, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands. 1414 Entered Leyte Gulf. Anchored in San Pedro Bay at 1739. (SOPA Rear Admiral GLOVER, Commander Service Force SEVENTH Fleet, at Tolosa, Leyte Island).

May 5. Anchored in San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands. (SOPA Rear Admiral GLOVER, Commander Service Force SEVENTH Fleet, at Tolosa, Leyte Island). 0713 Went alongside USS WHITNEY for repairs.

May 6. Moored alongside USS WHITNEY in San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands. (SOPA Rear Admiral GLOVER, Commander Service Force SEVENTH Fleet, at Tolosa, Leyte Island). Underway during the afternoon to fuel. 1839 Anchored in San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands.

May 7. Anchored in San Pedro Bay, Leyte lsland, Philippine Islands. (SOPA Rear Admiral GLOVER, Commander Service Force SEVENTH Fleet, at Tolosa, Leyte Island). 0557 Underway enroute from San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands, to Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT SIX secret dispatch 040156 of May 1945. Formed up Task Unit SEVENTY SIX POINT Six POINT FOUR consisting of USS DAY (Officer in Tactical Command), USS SAUFLEY, 5 AMSs and 2 YMSs.

May 8. Steaming enroute from San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands, to Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, in company with Task Unit SEVENTY SIa POINT SIX POINT FOUR consisting of USS DAY (Officer in Tactical Command), USS SAUFLEY, 5 AMSs and 2 YMSs.

May 9. Steaming enroute from San Pedro Bay, Leyte Isiand, Philippine Islands, to Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, in company with Task Unit SEVENTY SIX POINT SIX POINT FOUR consisting of USS DAY (Officer in Tactical Command), USS SAUFLEY, 5 AMSs and 2 YMSs. 1559 Entering Morotai anchorage, Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies. 1657 Anchored in Morotai anchorage, Morotai Island. (SOPA Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT).
May 10-14 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies. (SOPA Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT).

May 15 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies. (SOPA Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). 1330 Entered ARD 12, drydock, for hull inspection relative to hull structural damage of USS SAUFLEY incurred on 29 November 1944. 1732 Re-floated and returned to anchorage in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island. Hull inspection party (Commander W.N. PRICE, USN) found no serious hull damage sufficient to require docking repairs.
May 16 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies. (SOPA Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT).

May 17 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies. (SOPA Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). 0630 Underway in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT THIRTEEN dispatch 160446 of May 1945. Formed up with convoy consisting of USS BRANNON, 6 LSTs and the SS CHARLES LOOMIS. (Officer in Tactical Command in LST 595). Departed from Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, for San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Phil- ippine Islands. At 1156 developed sound contact. 1222 Dropped a nine charge medium pattern with no results. 1241 Contact non-sub; rejoined formation in accordance with screen commander's verbal orders.

May 18 Steaming enroute from Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, to San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands, in company with USS BRANNON, 6 LSTs and the SS CHARLES LOOMIS. (Officer in Tactical Command in LST 595). 1841 Developed sound contact. 1849 Sound contact evaluated as non-submarine; rejoined formation.

May 19 Steaming enroute from Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, to San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands, in company with USS BRANNON, 6 LSTs and the SS CHARLES LOOMIS. (Officer in Tactical Command in LST 595). 1710 USS BRANNON developed sound contact. At 1714 the contact was evaluated as non-submarine. USS BRANNON rejoined formation. In accordance with Screen Commander's dispatch 190804 left convoy and proceeded into Surigao Straits to report on shipping traffic in straits for convoy.

May 20 Steaming enroute from Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, to San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands, in company with USS BRANNON, 6 LSTs and the SS CHARLES LOOMIS. (Officer in Tactical Command in LST 595). SAUFLEY patrolling well ahead of convoy to report shipping traffic. Rejoined convoy at 0153 and resumed normal screening station. 0615 Detached from convoy by visual orders of the Screen Commander and proceeded into San Pedro Bay to fuel. Upon completion of fueling, moored alongside USS WHITNEY in San Pedro Bay for hull structural repairs. (SOPA, (Administrative) Commander Task Unit SEVENTY TWO POINT SEVEN POINT ONE in USS OTUS).
May 21-28 Moored alongside USS WHITNEY in San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands. (SOPA, (Administrative) Commander Task Unit SEVENTY TWO POINT SEVEN POINT ONE in USS OTUS).

May 29 Moored alongside USS WHITNEY in San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands. (SOPA, (Administrative) Commander Task Unit SEVENTY TWO POINT SEVEN POINT ONE in USS OTUS). 1330 Underway from alongside USS WHITNEY; proceeded to join USS PHILIP on firing range in Leyte Gulf, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands, for anti-aircraft practice. Completed anti-aircraft practice at 1706 and set course for Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, in company with USS PHILIP (Officer in Tactical Command) in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE dispatch 270053.

May 30 Steaming enroute from San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine lslands, to Morotai Island, Dutch East Indies, in company with USS PHILIP (Officer in Tactical Command). Fired off- set practice with USS PHILIP in the morning.

May 31 Steaming enroute from San Pedro Bay, Leyte Island, Philippine Islands, to Morotai island, Dutch Hast Indies, in company with USS PHILIP (Officer in Tactical Command). Fired anti-aircraft practice against towed sleeve in the morning. 1215 Entered Morotai Anchorage, fueled ship and moored alongside USS PHILIP at 1543. (SOPA Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT).

April 1. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY in U.S.S. SAUFLEY) enroute from Zamboanga, Mindanao, to Sanga Sanga, Sulu Archipelago.

April 2. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY in U.S.S. SAUFLEY) enroute from Zemboanga, Mindanao, to Sanga Sanga, Sulu Archipelago. At 0630 arrived off West coast of Ganga Sanga and conmenced landing operations beginning with mine sweep off landing beach. The first wave of troops landed at approximately 0800. SAUFLEY patrolled to Westward of transport area during landing operations.

At 1350 transport area received several bursts of what appeared to be 40M/M from Sange Sanga Island. Slight damage to several landing craft. No casualties.

At 1800 Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN POINT TWO (Captain SMITH in U.S.S. WALLER) departed for Zamboanga escorting first retirement group. During the night U.S.S. SAUFLEY and U.S.S. PHILIP screened 4 YMSs, and 2 LCSs during night retirement to the Southward into Celebes Sea.

April 3. Steaming on night retirement from Sanga Sanga Island, Sulu Archipelago. U.S.S. SAUFLEY (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN) and U.S.S. PHILIP screening 4 YMSs and 2 LCSs. Returned to transport area at 0830 and SAUFLEY commenced patrolling to seaward.

During the morning YMS 71 hit mine and sunk while conducting sweeping operations in Western entrance to Tawi Tawi Bay.

At night U.S.S. SAUFLEY (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN) and U.S.S. PHILIP screened retirement of 3 YMSs, 2 LSMs, 2 LCSs and 1 LST to the Southward into Celebes Sea.

April 4. Steaming on night retirement from Sanga Sanga, Sulu Archipelago. U.S.S. SAUFLEY (Officer in Tactical Coimand - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN) and U.S.S. PHILIP screening 3 YMSs, 2 LSMs, 2 LCSs and 1 LST, Returned to transport area at 0700 and commenced patrolling to Westward of transport area.

Departed Sanga Sanga at 1600 for Zamboanga with U.S.S. SAUFLEY and U.S.S. PHILIP screening 2 LSMs, 1 LST and 1 LCS.

April 5. Steaming enroute from Sanga Sanga, Sulu Archipelago to Zamboanga, Mindanao, in company with elements of Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). At 0030 3 YMSs and l LCS joined the formation. At 1130 in accordance with verbal orders of Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN departed from the formation and proceeded to Zamboanga. Arrived Zamboanga in late afternoon and anchored on Santa Cruz Bank at 1850.
April 6. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY).
April 7. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY).

April 8. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). During the morning underway to go alongside and fuel.

At 1600 formed Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN and departed Zamboanga for Jolo, Sulu Archipelago (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY in U.S.S. SAUFLEY).

April 9. Steaming enroute from Zamboanga, Mindanao, to Jolo, Sulu Archipelago, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN (officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY in U..S.S. SAUFLEY). Arrived Jolo Island, Sulu Archipelago, 0700, and screened landing craft as they took station in the transport area.

At 0746 commenced scheduled prelanding bombardment with U.S.S. WALLER and U.S.S. PHILIP. Ceased firing at 0828 having expended 201 rounds of 5"/38 AA Common. No casualties. Results undetermined. (See SAUFLEY action report serial 0145 of 11 April 1945).

Screened transport area until night retirement. At 1722 U.S.S. WALLER departed for Sanga Sanga escorting S.S. HARRISON EMERSON and several landing craft. At 1805 U.S.S. PHILIP departed for Zamboanga escorting units of Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN. SAUFLEY commenced night retirement to the Eastward at 1904 escorting one LST and 6 LCTs.

April 10. Steaming on night retirement Northeastward of Jolo Island, Sulu Archipelago escorting one LST and 6 LCTs. (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY ).

Returned to transport area at 0600 and commenced screening to seaward, At 1000 proceeded into harbor off Jolo Town and bombarded targets as requested by our forces ashore. Completed firing at 1204 having expended 53 rounds of 5"/38 AA Common ammunition. No casualties. Results reported very good. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 0145 of 11 April 1945). Commenced lying to in harbor.

At 1825 in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN's dispatch 100900 departed Jolo for Zamboanga escorting LST 459 and LSM 38.

April 11. Steaming enroute from Jolo, Sulu Archipelago to Zamboanga, Mindanao, P.I. escorting LST 459 and LSM 38. (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY.)

Arrived Zamboanga at 0700 and anchored on Santa Cruz Bank at 0746. At 1200 assumed ready duty in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN's dispatch 110300.

April 12. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). At 1200 relieved of ready duty by U.S.S. WALLER in accordance with Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO's dispatch 120135. At 1600 Captain GRAY relieved Captain J.D. MURPHY as Commander SEVENTH Amphibious Force Representative at Zamboanga.

April 13. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). Underway during morning to fuel. Assumed ready duty at 1200 in accordance with Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO's dispatch 130040. Returned to anchorage at 1244.

April 14. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). During morning Commanding Officer held personnel and living spaces inspection. At 1200 relieved of ready duty by U.S.S. PHILIP in accordance with Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO's dispatch 140155.
April 15. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). Assumed ready duty at 1200.
April 16. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). Relieved of ready duty at 1200 by U.S.S. PHILIP.
April 17. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). Assumed ready duty at 1200.
April 18. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). Relieved of ready duty at 1200 by U.S.S. PHILIP.

April 19. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). 1200 Relieved the U.S.S. PHILIP of ready duty. At 1900 Commander L. R. NEVILLE, #72477, U.S. Navy, relieved Captain C. W. GRAY, #57047, U.S. Navy, as Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN and Representative Commander SEVENTH Amphibious Force at Zamboanga in accordance with Commander SEVENTH Amphibious Force's dispatch 130122 of April 1945.

April 20. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). At 1920 underway in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT's dispatch 180134 of April 1945 and departed Zamboanga, Mindanao for Tawi Tawi, Sulu Archipelago.
April 21. Steaming enroute from Zamboanga, Mindanao, P.I. to Tawi Tawi, Sulu Archipelago, P.I. Entered Tawi Tawi Bay in the morning and anchored at 1156.

April 22-30. Anchored in Tawi Tawi Bay, Tawi Tawi Island, Sulu Archipelago, P.I. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander NEVILLE - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). On the afternoon of April 25, Senior Officer Present Afloat became Commander Task Group SEVENTY THREE POINT TWO in U.S.S. POCOMOKE.

March 1. Steaming enroute to Lubang Island, P.I., in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT NINE POINT SEVEN consisting of LCI's and LSM's. (Officer in Tactical Command in LCI 780). Screen composed of U.S.S. HAAS and U.S.S. SAUFLEY (Commander Screen and Commander Support Force). At 0715 arrived off landing beach, Tilic Town, and commenced pre-landing bombardment. Ceased firing at 0838 having expended 350 rounds of 5"/38 AA Common and 10 rounds of White Phosphorous ammunition. No casualties. Results apparently very good, Several large fires started. (See SAUFLEY action report serial 081 of 2 March 1945).

Reformed Task Unit at 1532 and departed for Mindoro via prescribed route.

March 2. Steaming enroute to Mindoro, P.I., in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT NINE POINT SEVEN consisting of LCI's and LSM's. (Officer in Tactical Command in LCI 780). Screen composed of U.S.S. HAAS and U.S.S. SAUFLEY. Arrived Mangarin Bay, Mindoro at 0525 and screened to seaward as Task Unit proceeded into port. Detached from Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT NINE POINT SEVEN at 0700 and departed for Subic Bay, Luzon, P.I.

Arrived Subic Bay at 1515 and anchored at 1555. Underway at 1825 to fuel. Returned to anchorage at 1950.

March 3. Anchored in Subic Bay, Luzon, P.I., Senior Officer Present Afloat, Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT Vice Admiral Barbey in U.S.S. BLUE RIDGE. Underway at 0818 and went alongside port side U.S.S. LAVALLETE in nest on port side of U.S.S. DOBBIN.

March 4-6. Moored in nest alongside port side of U.S.S. DOBBIN in berth #78, Subic Bay, Luzon, P.I., Senior Officer Present Afloat, Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT Vice Admiral Barbey in U.S.S. BLUE RIDGE.

March 7. Moored in nest alongside port side of U.S.S. DOBBIN in berth #78 Subic Bay, Luzon, P.I., Senior Officer Present Afloat, Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT Vice Admiral Barbey in U.S.S. BLUE RIDGE.

At 1805 underway from U.S.S. DOBBIN and proceeded out of Subic Bay. Took departure from Subic Bay for Mindoro, P.I., at 1844 in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT dispatch 070630.

March 8. Steaming enroute to Mindoro, P.I. Arrived Mindoro at 0545, entered Mangarin Bay, and fueled. Reported to Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE for duty in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT dispatch 070630. At 0730 joined screen of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE and took screening station in accordance with Sortie Plan. Took departure from Mindoro for Zamboanga at 0841 in accordance with Commander Amphibious Group SIX Attack Order A602-45. (Officer in Tactical Command, Rear Admiral Royal in U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT).

March 9. Steaming enroute to Zamboanga, Mindanao, P.I., in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral ROYAL in U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT). At 1655 echelon from Leyte consisting of seven LST's escorted by U.S.S. PHILIP and U.S.S. RUDDEROW joined the Task Group.

March 10. Steaming enroute to Zamboanga, Mindanao, P.I., in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral ROYAL in U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT). At 0630 ships of the Task Group commenced entering the transport area South of San Mateo, Zamboanga, Mindanao. SAUFLEY assumed anti-submarine screening station South of Great Santa Cruz Island at 0832.

At 1830 rendezvoused with Task Group SEVENTY FOUR POINT THREE composed of U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT (Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral ROYAL), U.S.S. PHOENIX, U.S.S. BOISE (Officer in Tactical Command Rear Admiral BERKEY), U.S.S. TAYLOR (CDS-21), U.S.S. NICHOLAS, U.S.S. O'BANNON, U.S.S. FLETCHER, U.S.S. JENKINS, U.S.S. ABBOTT, and U.S.S. PHILIP, in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY HIGHT POINT ONE, visual dispatch serial 100526. Conmenced night retirement to Westward of Zamboanga Peninsula.

March 11. Steaming on night retirement West of Zamboanga Peninsula, Mindanao, P.I., in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY FOUR POINT THREE composed of U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT (Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral ROYAL), U.S.S. PHOENIX, U.S.S. BOISE (Officer in Tactical Command Rear Admiral BERKEY), U.S.S. TAYLOR (Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY ONE), U.S.S. NICHOLAS, U.S.S. O'BANNON, U.S.S. FLETCHER, U.S.S. JENKINS, U.S.S. ABBOTT, U.S.S. PHILIP, and U.S.S. SAUFLEY.

Returned to transport area at 0700 and resumed patrol station in anti-submarine screen of the transport area. During afternoon picked up several natives who claimed to have information concerning Japanese on Basilan Island. These people transferred to U.S.S. WALLER (Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO) in accordance with verbal orders to Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO.

Joined U.S.S. PHILIP at 1800 in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE visual dispatch 110630 and took stations as night stand-by fire support ship's. SAUFLEY on station in outer fire support sector south of Little Santa Cruz Island. U.S.S. PHILIP on station in Basilan Strait north of Little Santa Cruze. SAUFLEY patrolled on courses generally east and west at a speed of ten (10) knots.

March 12. Patrolling on courses east and west in outer fire support sector south of Little Santa Cruz Island, Zamboanga, Mindanao, P.I., speed ten (10) knots. At 0100 relieved U.S.S. PHILIP in inner fire support sector north of Little Santa Cruz Island, Commenced lying to.

At 0615 relieved of fire support duty, underway, and proceeded out of Basilan Strait as directed verbally by Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE. Reported to Commander Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWO for duty and directed by him to resume anti-submarine screening station. At 1855 ceased patrolling and rendezvoused with U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral Royal), U.S.S. ROBINSON, and U.S.S. MCCALLA in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE visual dispatch 120630. Commenced night retirement to the westward of Zamboanga Peninsula.

March 13. Steaming on night retirement westward of Zamboanga Peninsula, Mindanao, Philippine Islands, in company with U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE - Rear Admiral ROYAL), U.S.S ROBINSON and U.S.S. MCCALLA. Returned to transport area off San Mateo at 0630 and took station in anti-submarine screen.

At 0753 took station North of Great Santa Cruz Island for fire support mission. Released from this duty at 1730 and joined U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT, U.S.S. PHILIP and U.S.S. MCCALLA for night retirement.

March 14. Steaming on night retirement Westward of Zamboanga Peninsula, Mindanao, Philippine Islands in company with U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE - Rear Admiral ROYAL), U.S.S. PHILIP and U.S.S. MCCALLA. Returned to transport area off San Mateo at 0645 and took station in anti-submarine screen.

Proceeded into anchorage area during morning and fueled from U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT. After fueling SAUFLEY returned to screening station in Basilan Strait.

Assumed fire support duty at 1730. Shifted to screening station West of Caldera Point.

March 15. Patrolling on anti-submarine screening station West of Caldera Point standing by as fire support ship (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO - Captain SMITH in U.S.S. WALLER).

Relieved of fire support duty at 0730.

At 1600 proceeded to transport area and received ammunition from LST 1026 in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE's visual dispatch 150006. Upon completion assumed station in anti-submarine screen.

March 16. Patrolling on anti-submarine screening station in Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO - Captain SMITH in U.S.S. WALLER).

At 0630 proceeded to Santa Cruz Bank in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE's dispatch 150725 [illegible]. Underway at 0830 in company with U.S.S. WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO - Captain SMITH) escorting landing craft to Basilan Island.

Arrived off Lamitan Town, Basilan Island at 0940 Commenced prelanding bombardment at 0942. Ceased firing at 1059 having expended 198 rounds of 5"/38 AA Common and 10 rounds of white phosphorous. No casualties. Results reported good. (See SAUFLEY action report serial 092 of 18 March 1945). At 1100 troops landed. SAUFLEY and WALLER standing by for fire support.

At 1630 returned to Zamboanga transport area in accordance with Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO's verbal orders and took station in anti-submarine screen.

March 17. Patrolling on anti-submarine screening station in Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE - Rear Admiral ROYAL in U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT).

At 0600 in accordance with verbal orders of Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO joined U.S.S. WALLER and proceeded to Basilan Island off Lamitan Town for fire support duty. At 1030 in accordance with verbal orders of Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE returned to Zamboanga transport area in company with U.S.S. WALLER. Took station in anti-submarine sereen.

March 18. Patrolling on anti-submarine screening station in Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE - Rear Admiral ROYAL in U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT). At 1600 joined Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWENTY composed of U.S.S. WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain SMITH - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO), U.S.S. PHILIP, U.S.S. SAUFLEY, 8 LST's and 19 LSM's in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE's dispatch 171411. Departed Zamboanga for Mindoro at 1650.

March 19. Steaming enroute from Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands to Mindoro, Philippine Islands in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWENTY (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO - Captain SMITH in U.S.S. WALLER.

March 20. Steaming enroute from Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands to Mindoro, Philippine Islands in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWENTY (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO - Captain SMITH in U.S.S. WALLER.

During the morning entered Mangarin Bay, Mindoro, Philippine Islands, fueled, received provisions, and anchored at 1907.
March 21. Anchored in Mangarin Bay, Mindoro, Philippine Islands (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Group SEVENTY TWO POINT TEN at Red Beach).

March 22. Anchored in Mangarin Bay, Mindoro, Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TEN at Red Beach). Underway at 1047 in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE dispatch 171411. Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWENTY reformed consisting of U.S.S. WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command Captain SMITH - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO), U.S.S. PHILIP, U.S.S. SAUFLEY, 8 LST's, 5 LSM's and U.S.S. CARONDOLET. This Task Unit departed Mindoro for Zamboanga at 1208.

March 23. Steaming enroute from Mindoro, Philippine Islands to Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWENTY (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO - Captain SMITH in U.S.S. WALLER).

March 24. Steaming enroute from Mindoro, Philippine Islands to Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWENTY (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO - Captain SMITH in U.S.S. WALLER).

Arrived Zamboanga at 0700, SAUFLEY anchored on Santa Cruz Bank at 0810. Underway at 1039 and went alongside U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT in order to fuel ship. At 1515 in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE's visual dispatch 232215 Captain J.D. MURPHY, Representative of Commander SEVENTH Fleet Amphibious Force, came on board with his staff.

SAUFLEY underway at 1530 and proceeded to anchorage on Santa Cruz Bank.

At 1800 Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral ROYAL, in U.S.S. ROCKY MOUNT departed this area. In accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE's dispatch Captain MURPHY assumed duties of Senior Officer Present Afloat and became Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN.
March 25. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY).

March 26. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY).

At 1600 in accordance with Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO dispatch 252205 SAUFLEY assumed duties as ready duty ship relieving U.S.S. WALLER.

March 27. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY).

At 1600 relieved from ready duty by U.S.S. PHILIP in accordance with Commander Task Unit SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN POINT TWO dispatch 270110.
March 28. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands, (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S SAUFLEY).

March 29. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). At 1800 assumed ready duty in accordance with Coumander Task Unit SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN POINT TWO dispatch 280245.

March 30. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). At 1800 relieved of the ready duty by the U.S.S. WALLER.

March 31. Anchored on Santa Cruz Bank, Basilan Strait, Mindanao, Philippine Islands (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN in U.S.S. SAUFLEY). Underway at 1744 in accordance with Commander SEVENTH Amphibious Forces Representative, Zamboanga Attack Order Al-45. Formed Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN composed of U.S.S. SAUFLEY (Officer in Tactical Command - Captain MURPHY - Commander Task Group SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN), U.S.S. WALLER (Commander Task Unit SEVENTY SIX POINT TEN POINT TWO - Captain SMITH - Sereen Commander), U.S.S. PHILIP, 4 YMS's, 1 SC, 1 LST, 6 LSM's and 9 LCI's. At 1800 departed Zamboanga for Sanga Sanga Island, Sulu Archipelago.

June 1 Moored starboard side to USS PHILIP in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island, Netherlands East Indies. (SOPA, Com- mander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). 0815 USS PHILIP underway from alongside. SAUFLEY anchored. 1242 Underway and proceeded to go alongside USS GADSDEN for ammunition. Returned to anchorage area at 1633 and moored port side to USS PHILIP.

June 2 Moored port side to USS PHILIP in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island, Netherlands East Indies. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). Underway at 1534 to fuel. Completed fueling at 1636 and moored port side to USS PHILIP at 1730.

June 3 Moored port side to USS PHILIP in Morotai Harbor, Morotai Island, Netherlands Hast Indies. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). Underway at 0614 in accordance with Commander Amphibious Group SIX Attack Order A606-45. At 1032 formed Slow Tow Convoy composed of MS MATTHEW FLINDERS, HMAS TIGERSNAKE and TY 35, TY 46, LT 225, TP 108, and TP 230, towing gas barges, Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY. This unit departed Morotai for Brunei Bay, British North Borneo.

June 4 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY.

June 5 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY.

June 6 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY.

June 7 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY. At 0500 detached from convoy and directed to proceed ahead to Zamboanga, Mindanao, Philippine Islands and fuel. Arrived Zamboanga at 0800. Completed fueling from USS STONEWALL at 1440 and rejoined the convoy at 1530 at Eastern end of Basilan strait. USS WALLER proceeded ahead to Zamboanga for fueling at 1535. Lieutenant Commander SILK in USS SAUFLEY became Officer in Tactical Command.

June 8 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies, to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS SAUFLEY (Officer in Tactical Command, Lieutenant Commander SILK). At 0550 USS WALLER rejoined convoy and Commander THOMPSON became Officer in Tactical Command.

June 9 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies, to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY.

June 10 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies, to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY.

June 11 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY. At 0710 HMAS HAWKESBURY escorting ST 384 and tow joined the convoy.

June 12 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON), HMAS HAWKESBURY and USS SAUFLEY.

June 13 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON), HMAS HAWKESBURY and USS SAUFLEY.

June 14 Enroute from Morotai, Netherlands East Indies to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo escorting Slow Tow Gasoline Convoy. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON), HMAS HAWKESBURY and USS SAUFLEY. During the morning entered Brunei Bay and reported to Commander Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWO for duty. At 1030 relieved USS ROBINSON on Screening Station in Xray-8 in accordance with orders of Commander Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWO, Screen Commander. At 1318 relieved on station by APD 61 and proceeded into Victoria Harbor to fuel. Completed fueling at 1751, proceeded out of Victoria Harbor, and anchored in patrol station Xray-4, Brunei Bay, as directed by Commander Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWO. Two air alerts during the evening.

June 15 Anchored in Brunei Bay, British North Borneo. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE, Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). Underway at 0858 and proceeded to radar picket station as directed by Commander Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT TWO. Relieved USS BANCROFT on station at 1004. At 1424 relieved on station by USS BANCROFT and proceeded into VICTORIA Harbor and anchored. Underway at 1748 in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and departed Brunei Bay for Miri-Lutong area in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE dispatch 141151 of June 1945. At 2303 relieved USS PHILIP and USS EDWARDS as Screen for Sweeping Unit, Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT FIVE.

June 16 Steaming in company with Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT FIVE on night retirement from Miri-Lutong Area, Sarawak. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY. During the morning mine sweepers continued operations. WALLER and SAUFLEY followed sweeps into cleared area and anchored off Lutong Town, Sarawak, at 1214. Underway at 1807 and proceeded out to sea. At 2046 formed cruising disposition with mine-sweeps and commenced night retirement.

June 17 Steaming in company with Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT FIVE on night retirement from Miri-Lutong Area, Sarawak. Screen composed of USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SAUFLEY.

During the morning returned to area and anchored off Lutong Town while sweeps continued operations. Underway at 1805 and stood out of area. In accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE dispatch 160247 of June 1945 USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON), USS SENTRY and USS SAUFLEY departed for Brunei Bay at 1900. At 2156 USS WALLER departed formation and Lieutenant Commander SILK in USS SAUFLEY became Officer in Tactical Command. USS WALLER rejoined at 2305 and Commander THOMPSON became Officer in Tactical Command.

June 18 Steaming in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SENTRY enroute from Miri, Sarawak, to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo. During the morning entered Brunei Bay, proceeded into Victoria Harbor, and anchored at 0729.

Underway at 1601 in company with USS WALLER in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE dispatch 150509 and formed Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON in USS WALLER). At 1642 departed Brunei Bay for Morotai, Halmahera Group.

June 19 Enroute from Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, to Morotai, Halmahera Group, in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) as Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX.

June 20 Enroute from Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, to Morotai, Halmahera Group, in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) as Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX.

June 21 Enroute from Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, to Morotai, Halmahera Group, in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) as Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX

During the morning entered Morotai Harbor, fueled, and anchored at 1017.
June 22 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 2 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH). Underway at 1212 in accordance with Commander Amphibious Group EIGHT Rehearsal Order 1-45 for Rehearsal Landing with Ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. Proceeded out of Harbor and screened sortie of transports. Formed cruising disposition and departed at 1457.

June 24 Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO enroute to Rehearsal Landing area. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

During the morning Rehearsal Landing carried out on Southeast coast of Morotai Island. SAUFLEY acted as screening ship and simulated fire support ship during this time. Upon completion of Rehearsal SAUFLEY directed by Commander Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO POINT FIFTEEN, Commander Screen, to join USS FLUSSER and PC 1134 as screen for LST's returning to staging area. SAUFLEY returned to Morotai Harbor with this group and anchored at 1745.

June 25 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH). Underway during morning to fuel. Moored alongside USS PHILIP at 1037.

June 26 Moored starboard side to USS PHILIP in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH). Underway at 1217 in accordance with Commander Amphibious Group SIX Attack Order 6-45 to screen sortie of transport units. At 1455 Task Group formed cruising disposition and departed Morotai for Balikpapan, Borneo. During afternoon ships of screen fired AA practice at a towed sleeve.

June 2 Enroute from Morotai, Halwmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 28 Enroute from Morotai, Halmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 29 Enroute from Morotai, Halmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 30 Enroute from Morotai, Halmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Coimand, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

January 1. Enroute from Seeadler Harbor, Manus Island to Humboldt Bay, New Guinea. At 0540 entered Humboldt Bay, fueled, and anchored in destroyer anchorage area. In accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY SEVEN POINT NINE's secret dispatch 310130 of December underway from Humboldt Bay at 0936 and proceeded to rendezvous with Task Force SEVENTY NINE.

January 2. Enroute from Humboldt Bay, New Guinea to rendezvous with Task Force SEVENTY NINE. At O410 contacted Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO. After transferring intelligence material to flagships of Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE, Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE and Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO joined anti-submarine screen of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS).

January 3. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO enroute from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS) (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SiVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). Several sound contacts were reported and investigated by screening ships during the afternoon, but no positive proof of the presence of enemy submarines.

January 4. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO enroute from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS), (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). During the morning anti-aircraft gunnery practice was conducted by the transports between 0930 and 1030. From 1330 to 1430 the transports conducted tactical exercises. Ships of the screen reported two sound contacts during the early afternoon, but no positive proof of the presence of enemy submarines.

January 5. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO enroute from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS), (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). During the morning the ships of the screen fueled. At 1428 detached from Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO and proceeded to join Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE as directed by verbal orders of Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO.

January 6. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE enroute from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). At 0421 entered Leyte Gulf, then proceeded South through Surigao Straits and into Mindanao Sea. The Combat Air Patrol shot down a Jill inside the formation at 1712. Entered the Sulu Sea around 2030.

January 7. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE enroute from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). During the morning the ships of the screen fueled. The Task Group passed through Cuyo East Pass in the morning entering the China Sea in late afternoon.

January 8. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE enroute from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). At 1630 Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE closed Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO taking position close astern. Task Force SEVENTY NINE was attacked by eight to ten enemy planes (Vals and Zekes) at 1810, Combat Air Patrol shot down four Vals on the port quarter of the formation at approximately 1820. At 1858 observed one suicide plane crash into the port quarter of the USS KITKUN BAY. SAUFLEY opened fire at 1904 on single Val crossing astern. This plane crashed close aboard one of the transports. At 1935 area clear of enemy planes. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945).

January 9. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE enroute from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). This Task Group in company with other groups of the attack force entered Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island prior to sunrise and commenced scheduled attack plan. SAUFLEY lying to screening Task Force SEVENTY NINE transport area. During the day there were several light air attacks, SAUFLEY fired on planes as opportunity permitted during a sunset attack. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945).

January 10. Lying to screening Task Force SEVENTY NINE transport area, Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island. At sunrise shipping in the gulf was attacked by Japanese planes, SAUFLEY opened fire on various planes as opportunity permitted. At 0720 Val attempted to crash into the SAUFLEY and missed, crashing into the sea approximately fifteen yards on the starboard bow. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945). During the day screened Task Force SEVENTY NINE transport area, At 1735 screened transports enroute from Lingayen transport area to San Fabian transport area.

January 11. Scereening to the South of the San Fabian transport area, Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island. During the morning screened USS MOUNT OLYMPUS, USS ROCKY MOUNT, and USS MOUNT MCKINLEY enroute from the San Fabian transport area to the Lingayen transport area. At 1000 resumed screening Lingayen transport area. A suspicious small craft attempted to close this ship at 2257, but was evaded and disappeared.

January 12. Screening to the Westward of the Lingayen transport area, Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island. Enemy aircraft attacked shipping at 0800. SAUFLEY fired on enemy planes at 0803 and 0805. No results observed. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945). At 1020 proceeded to San Fabian transport area to fuel as directed by Screen Commander. Fueling interrupted by report of enemy planes in area at 1158. Returned to Lingayen and resumed screening transport area at 1223. In accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE's dispatch 120436 formed up with Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN) at 1800 and departed Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island for Leyte Gulf.

January 13. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX enroute from Lingayen Gulf, Luzon to Leyte Gulf. (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN). At 0820 the formation was attacked by a single Japanese plane which evaded the Combat Air Patrol in the clouds and crashed into the USS ZEILIN. SAUFLEY recovered one survivor from the sea at 0840.

January 14. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX enroute from Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island to Leyte Gulf. (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN). There were several air alerts during the day, but the formation was never attacked.

January 15. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX enroute from Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island to Leyte Gulf. (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN). During the afternoon the formation entered Leyte Gulf and anchored in the Abuyog Transport area. At 1734 the SAUFLEY anchored approximately one mile East of Abuyog Transport area.

January 16. Anchored one mile Hast of Abuyog transport area Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. In accordance with verbal orders of Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO underway at 1020 and proceeded to San Pedro Bay where SAUFLEY fueled, loaded ammunition, and anchored in vicinity of berth #25 at 1957.

January 17. Anchored in vicinity of berth #25, San Pedro Bay, Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. During the morning SAUFLEY shifted berths to be closer to provision ship. Underway at 1645 as directed by Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO and proceeded out of San Pedro Bay to Abuyog transport area. Anchored one mile East of the transport area at 1827. During air alert at 2040 underway and laid smoke screen to the East of transport. area as directed by Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO. Returned to anchorage at 2133. Area clear of enemy planes.

January 18. Anchored one mile Hast of Abuyog transport area Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. In accordance with Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO dispatch 180500 underway at 1700 to rendezvous with Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE. At 1800 formed Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE composed of Transport Division FORTY ONE, FORTY TWO, TWENTY ONE (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division FORTY ONE in USS LATIMER) and USS SIGOURNEY, USS PHILIP, USS WALLER and USS SAUFLEY as screen. This Task Group then took departure from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Island for Manus Island and Morotai Island.

January 19. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE enroute from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands to Manus Island and Morotai Island. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division FORTY ONE in USS LATIMER).

January 20. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE enroute from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands to Manus Island and Morotai Island. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division FORTY ONE in USS LATIMER). At 0205 USS SIGOURNEY and USS SAUFLEY formed sereen for Transport Division TWENTY ONE and became Task Unit SEVENTY BIGHT POINT FIVE POINT Two (Officer in Tactical Command Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA). This unit departed from main group and set course for Morotai Island.

January 21. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE POINT TWO enroute from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands to Morotai Island. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA). During the morning SAUFLEY screened to seaward as the transports proceeded to anchorage and then anchored off Southwest shore of Morotai Island at 0918. At 1110 Lieutenant Commander Francis W. SILK reported on board for duty as prospective Commanding Officer. Underway at 1330 to fuel. Returned to anchorage at 1857.
January 22.-24. Anchored off the Southwest shore of Morotai Island. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA).

January 25. Anchored off the Southwest shore of Morotai Island. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA). Underway at 0612 as directed by Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE dispatch 242228 of January and took departure from Morotai Island for Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands.

January 26. Enroute from Morotai Island to Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. Passed through Eastern Surigao Strait at 1425 and entered Leyte Gulf. At 1516 entered San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands, fueled, and anchored in berth #456 at 2006. Reported to Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT for duty in accordance with Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE dispatch 242228 of January.
January 27. Anchored in berth #456, San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands.
January 28, Anchored in berth #456, San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands.

January 29. Anchored in berth #456, San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands. At 0728 underway in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT dispatch 280624 of January and formed Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWELVE POINT SIX with CGC INGHAM enroute to Luzon, Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command in CGC INGHAM).

January 30. Steaming enroute from Leyte to Luzon, Philippine Islands escorting CGC INGHAM. (Officer in Tactical Command in CGC INGHAM). At 1135 directed by Officer in Tactical Command to proceed to Agutaya Island and search for survivors of downed friendly plane. Arrived at Agutaya Island at 1238 and sighted survivors on beach at 1243. Army rescue craft P493 arrived in vicinity and assumed task of recovering survivors from the beach. At 1330 SAUFLEY departed Agutaya Island to rejoin CGC INGHAM prior dark as directed. Rejoined CGC INGHAM at 1743 West of Mindoro Island.

January 31. Steaming enroute from Leyte to Luzon, Philippine Islands escorting CGC INGHAM. (Officer in Tactical Command in OGG INGHAM). At 0800 arrived San Antonio area West coast Luzon where Task Unit dissolved and SAUFLEY reported to Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT THREE for duty in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT THREE dispatch 281624, At 1015 departed San Antonio escorting USS GRASP enroute to Nasugbu as directed verbally by Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT THREE. Arrived Nasugbu Cove, Luzon, Philippine Islands at 1655 and reported for duty to Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO and relieved USS RUSSELL as directed by Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT dispatch 291247. At night retired to the Westward of Nasugbu in company with CGC SPENCER (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO - Rear Admiral FECHTELER) and USS CONYNGHAM.
